meta.author: JA
meta.for_whom: The Institute for Art and Olfaction
meta.further_comments: I live in Minneapolis and the first thing I thought of when I thought of blue, we have these super cold snowy days where the sky is intense blue and when you walk outside your nose freezes because it's 30 degrees below zero. So I was going for that day. It's a real moment when that happens. And I kept it really simple because as I mixed in more things I found it got really complicated and I'm kind of a minimalist. So I mixed aquamate, menthone and stryallyl acetate -- just three things and I just tried a whole bunch of variations until I found one I liked. But I've never done this before so it was really an experiment.

meta.author: Chacha Sikes
meta.for_whom: The Institute for Art and Olfaction
meta.further_comments: This one is the smell of a blue pigment. It felt like the adoxal and aquamate give it a high-pitched mineral feeling and the terpineol and meijiff is more predominant and give it a sweet but mellow blue, which is how I feel about the color blue. And then I wanted to ground it because it's an earth pigment not a water blue, which has to do more with physics, so there's a tiny bit of chamomile, tansy blue — which actually the first time I smelled it was the most cornflower, so I wanted to use it — and vetiver and cyclamen. I feel like cyclamen — I used just a bit of it -- but it felt blue and even and linear. So that's my blue.

meta.author: Daniel Krasofski
meta.for_whom: The Institute for Art and Olfaction
meta.further_comments: Blue comfy cozy one of the ideas I was thinking of was creating the frozen corner of a window in winter when there's a crust of ice on the corner -- that's what I was going for, don't know if I did it. This is kind of an idea where I was going with that... I used a total of 10 ingredients, the cozy comfy concepts come from ionone beta, cashmeran, tonalide, terpineol, which gives it a round cozy comfy feeling. Damascone beta and amber key accord and blue chamomile -- the azuline in the chamomile gave it a kind of softness -- amber and damascone gave it a cool and cozy quality. For more of a zing, which was the top notes, was the basil and a little bit of the linalool to give it a crisp, clean quality. It's not exactly what I was striving for, but it's got an interesting blue quality to it.

meta.author: Rachel Weiler
meta.for_whom: The Institute for Art and Olfaction
meta.further_comments: We're also novice smellers. So I'm a trainee therapist and the subject made me think of the Mammalian Diving Reflex that we use in dialectical behavior therapy. The idea is that when you submerge your face in cold water or ice, your body starts to slow your heart beat and bring your blood to your core. It's because it helps you to survive underwater, we were diving mammals, but for people it's a great way to calm down. Blue just made me think of that. The perfume is supposed to have a cold shock and a warm and comforting element. For the cold we used menthone and cadaverine, which is gross but it worked okay, and the turmeric and vetiver were the more comforting elements. We used a fair amount of tansy blue which didn't smell cold to me on its own but worked okay.

meta.author: Rubia Chaudri
meta.for_whom: The Institute for Art and Olfaction
meta.further_comments: The thought process behind mine was, when we were learning about the color blue and talking about the lapis lazuli and Afghanistan, I have been to parts of those terrains and I was thinking about the dark night with the dryness of the bush and the smell of gunmetal and the little bit of the shine that comes through. So I added some freshness with the azuril and ionone beta and I created the inky stone effect for the cold night that I wanted with the turmeric, terpineol and ultrazur, and the shine I used the tonalide and amber, and for the dry bush I used basil and vetiver. Stone, fresh, midnight scent.

meta.author: Willa Zheng
meta.for_whom: The Institute for Art and Olfaction
meta.further_comments: My concept for the brief was a warm, cozy, 'blue' scent. I was inspired by the Amber Key Accord we were given to work with. As such I wanted to paint an olfactory picture of a medium to deep toned Blue. I added Cyclamen Aldehyde and Damascone Beta to give a floral aspect to the Amber base. Meijiff and Tonalide gave it some woody base. I consciously avoided notes that would make the finished product smell ozonic. The submitted sample is not quite finished but it reminds me of the sapphire gemstone.

meta.author: Madeleine Stearn
meta.for_whom: The Institute for Art and Olfaction
meta.further_comments: Design concept: What does it smell like to be infected by something as so crippling as the devil's darkness, your body drunk and sweating of fear, nausea, so unfathomable your body turns to knots. Sound horrible? It is. The palette I went for was intended to create a visceral reaction. The drunk whiskey benzoin, with the decaying sweaty notes of body (tropathiane) lays in the garlic attempts of cure. Needing some light at the end of the tunnel? Walk through Connor's transformative processual state to greet Rubia's light at the end of the tunnel. Material notes: I used tropathione, indole, for the sweat of body. The benzoin and rhubafuran gave it the out, but for a zing which needed the amber of the end of the tunnel? Then I used cade and myrrh for the atmosphere around the rhuburufan which is what is being released out of the body, an alcoholic and garlicky kind of go.

meta.author: Connor
meta.for_whom: The Institute for Art and Olfaction
meta.further_comments: Design concept: I pictured in my head an old woman in the process of possession. Laying in her bed in a musty room built years before her birth. The walls are cold. The scent of beauty and death reign on me. The fight in her inspires me but I know it's near. I can see her realm of existence slipping away as the wicked takes control.

meta.author: MR
meta.for_whom: The Institute for Art and Olfaction
meta.further_comments: not just the smell of a mountain lion but also the dry scrubby area it lives in and the synthetic note of its tracking collar -- other participants described this as 'a firework.' A response to Helen McClory's short fiction about LA mountain lion, P‑22.

meta.author: Rubia Chaudri
meta.for_whom: The Institute for Art and Olfaction
meta.further_comments: Design concept: The overall story of this scent was to capture or bring a sense of peace at the beginning before exorcisms and after, even though darkness remained. The scent captures the smell of a stone built church set in Europe bringing in the crispness of fall. The smell of rose highlights the feeling of hope through despair and the image of purity the church represented.
